newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Police stop ultra-Orthodox Jews from closing street.
newsitem.headline: Police stop ultra-Orthodox Jews from closing street.

text.p: Hundreds of ultra-Orthodox Jews tried on Saturday to close a Jerusalem street that Israel's High Court ruled earlier in the week should be open to traffic on the sabbath, witnesses said.
Witnesses said police held back hundreds of religious Jews in traditional black garb who tried to block traffic on Bar Ilan street, a main Jerusalem thoroughfare.

The court ruling on Sunday ended an unofficial eight-month truce along Bar-Ilan street and drew threats from members of the ultra-Orthodox community to renew weekly Saturday protests against the road being open.
Police increased their presence on the street following the court decision.
The ruling cancelled last year's decision by Transportation Minister Yitzhak Levy, an Orthodox Jew, to close Bar-Ilan street during prayer times on the sabbath and Jewish holidays.
Ultra-Orthodox Jews had suspended their protests pending the court's decision on left-wing appeals against Levy's edict.
Jewish ritual law forbids the operation of machinery, including automobiles, on the sabbath which runs from Friday night to Saturday night.
